gw.api.databuilder

Class DataBuilder<T extends Bean,B extends DataBuilder<T,B>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.databuilder.DataBuilder<T,B>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ValueGenerator<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ABContactAddressBuilder, ABContactBuilder, ABContactBuilder.ABContactSpecialistServiceBuilder, ABContactBuilder.ABContactTagBuilder, ABContactCategoryScoreBuilder, ABContactContactBuilder, ActivityPatternBaseBuilder, com.guidewire.pl.domain.contact.AddressBaseBuilder, AttributeBuilder, AttributeUserBuilder, BusinessWeekBuilder, BusinessWeekZoneBuilder, ContactAddressBuilder, ContactBuilder, ContactContactBuilder, ContactTagBuilder, CredentialBuilder, DuplicateContactBatchRunBuilder, DuplicateContactPairBuilder, EFTDataBuilder, ExchangeRateBuilder, ExchangeRateSetBuilder, com.guidewire.pl.domain.community.GroupBaseBuilder, GroupRegionBuilder, GroupUserBuilder, HolidayBuilder, HolidayTagBuilder, HolidayZoneBuilder, MessageBaseBuilder, MessageHistoryBuilder, OfficialIDBuilder, com.guidewire.pl.domain.community.OrganizationBaseBuilder, PendingContactChangeBuilder, ProcessHistoryBuilder, RegionBuilder, RegionZoneBuilder, ReviewSummaryBuilder, ReviewSummaryBuilder.ReviewSummaryCategoryScoreBuilder, RoleBuilder, RolePrivilegeBuilder, SecurityZoneBuilder, SpecialistServiceBaseBuilderBase, com.guidewire.pl.domain.community.UserBaseBuilder, UserRoleBuilder, UserSettingsBuilder, WorkflowBuilder, ZoneBuilder

    public class DataBuilder<T extends Bean,B extends DataBuilder<T,B>>
extends Object
implements ValueGenerator<T>
    Base data "builder" class. Provides a facility for setting up property values and creating beans with those values. When {@link #create(gw.pl.persistence.core.Bundle)}, {@link #create(gw.pl.persistence.core.Bundle)}, or {@link #create()} execute, properties and populators are set and executed in ascending order according to their "order" values. Those with the same order value are executed according to the order in which they were set or added.

      Gets the last bean created by this builder, or null if {@link #create(gw.pl.persistence.core.Bundle)} has not yet been called.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Object addPopulator(int order, BeanPopulator<Bean> populator)
      Adds a {@link gw.api.databuilder.populator.BeanPopulator} to the builder with the given order value. The populator will be assigned a unique ID, so that it can be referred to in future calls to {@link #getPopulator(Object)} or {@link #removePopulator(Object)}.
      Object addPopulator(BeanPopulator<Bean> populator)
      Adds a {@link gw.api.databuilder.populator.BeanPopulator} to the builder with an order value of ({@link #DEFAULT_ORDER}). The populator will be assigned a unique ID, so that it can be referred to in future calls to {@link #getPopulator(Object)} or {@link #removePopulator(Object)}.
      Bean create(Bundle bundle)
      Creates an instance of this builder's entity type, with values determined by prior calls to {@link #set(gw.lang.reflect.IPropertyInfo , Object)}.
      Bean create()
      Creates an instance of this builder's entity type, in the default bundle. The default bundle is reset before every test class and method.
      Bean createAndCommit()
      Creates an instance of this builder's entity type, in the default bundle, and commits the bundle.
      Bean createAndCommitInNewBundle()
      Creates an instance of this builder's entity type, in a new bundle, and commits the bundle.
      Bean createInNewBundle()
      Creates an instance of this builder's entity type, in a new bundle.
      static com.guidewire.testharness.taghandlers.EnvironmentTagHandler getTestEnvironmentHandler()
      static void resetDefaultBundle()
      Package-protected for {@link gw.api.databuilder.BCDataBuilder} (BC) only. Once that's gone we can make it private.
      ValueGenerator<Bean> share()
      Returns a wrapper around this builder which can be handed to any method expecting a ValueGenerator<T>. The effect of this wrapper is to make sure that the builder is only called once as part of any create call. For example given: MainBuilder mainBuilder = new MainBuilder(); SubBuilder subBuilder = new SubBuilder(); Main main = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create(); You would normally get two entirely different Sub objects created; the SubBuilder would be called twice and the Main object would end up with field1 and field2 referencing two different objects. But if you did this: MainBuilder mainBuilder = new MainBuilder(); ValueGenerator<Sub> subBuilder = new SubBuilder().share(); Main main = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create(); The SubBuilder would only be called once and you'd have a single Main object whose field1 and field2 both reference a single Sub object. Note that the sharing only happens for a particular create call. A create call to create a graph of beans will only call the shared builder once. But an entirely separate create call will call it again e.g: MainBuilder mainBuilder = new MainBuilder(); ValueGenerator<Sub> subBuilder = new SubBuilder().share(); Main main1 = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create(); Main main2 = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create(); Will create two Main objects, each of them pointing to a single Sub object. But the Sub object for main1 will be different from the one for main2
      DataBuilder<T,B> withPublicId(String publicId)
      Assigns the given public id value to the entity to be created, overriding the default auto-generation behavior.
      static ValueGenerator<KeyableBean> wrapBean(KeyableBean bean)
      Utility, takes any bean and wraps it in an ExistingBean object so it can be passed to any method that takes a ValueGenerator<T>. This is useful when creating withXXX methods that can take either a bean or a builder. First create a core method that takes a ValueGenerator<T>; all builders are value generators so this method will accept a builder. To provide an overloaded method that takes a bean, add a method whose body is withXXX(wrapBean(bean)).
      static ValueGenerator<Object> wrapValue(Object value)
      Utility, takes any value and wraps it in a ValueGenerator<T>. This is useful when creating withXXX methods that can take either a raw value or a ValueGenerator. First create a core method that takes a ValueGenerator<T>. To provide an overloaded method that takes a raw value, add a method whose body is withXXX(wrapValue(T)).

      • addPopulator

        Object addPopulator(int order,
                  BeanPopulator<Bean> populator)
        Adds a {@link gw.api.databuilder.populator.BeanPopulator} to the builder with the given order value. The populator will be assigned a unique ID, so that it can be referred to in future calls to {@link #getPopulator(Object)} or {@link #removePopulator(Object)}.
        Parameters:
        order - used to select when this populator gets executed during {@link #create(gw.pl.persistence.core.Bundle)}
        populator - the populator to execute during {@link #create(gw.pl.persistence.core.Bundle)}
        Returns:
        the ID assigned to the given populator.

        Parameters:
        populator - the populator to execute during {@link #create(gw.pl.persistence.core.Bundle)}
        Returns:
        the ID assigned to the given populator.

      • share

        ValueGenerator<Bean> share()
        Returns a wrapper around this builder which can be handed to any method expecting a ValueGenerator<T>. The effect of this wrapper is to make sure that the builder is only called once as part of any create call. For example given: 
          MainBuilder mainBuilder = new MainBuilder();
  SubBuilder subBuilder = new SubBuilder();
  Main main = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create();
        You would normally get two entirely different Sub objects created; the SubBuilder would be called twice and the Main object would end up with field1 and field2 referencing two different objects. But if you did this: 
          MainBuilder mainBuilder = new MainBuilder();
  ValueGenerator<Sub> subBuilder = new SubBuilder().share();
  Main main = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create();
        The SubBuilder would only be called once and you'd have a single Main object whose field1 and field2 both reference a single Sub object.

        Note that the sharing only happens for a particular create call. A create call to create a graph of beans will only call the shared builder once. But an entirely separate create call will call it again e.g: 

          MainBuilder mainBuilder = new MainBuilder();
  ValueGenerator<Sub> subBuilder = new SubBuilder().share();
  Main main1 = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create();
  Main main2 = mainBuilder.withSubField1(subBuilder).withSubField2(subBuilder).create();
        Will create two Main objects, each of them pointing to a single Sub object. But the Sub object for main1 will be different from the one for main2
        Returns:
        a new value generator that will call the wrapped builder only once per create call

      • withPublicId

        DataBuilder<T,B> withPublicId(String publicId)
        Assigns the given public id value to the entity to be created, overriding the default auto-generation behavior.
        Parameters:
        publicId - the value to use for the public id. If null, the entity will be assigned one automatically on commit.
        Returns:

      • wrapBean

        ValueGenerator<KeyableBean> wrapBean(KeyableBean bean)
        Utility, takes any bean and wraps it in an ExistingBean object so it can be passed to any method that takes a ValueGenerator<T>. This is useful when creating withXXX methods that can take either a bean or a builder. First create a core method that takes a ValueGenerator<T>; all builders are value generators so this method will accept a builder. To provide an overloaded method that takes a bean, add a method whose body is withXXX(wrapBean(bean)).
        Parameters:
        bean - the bean to be wrapped
        Returns:
        a new value generator that will return the given bean when its create method is called

      • wrapValue

        ValueGenerator<Object> wrapValue(Object value)
        Utility, takes any value and wraps it in a ValueGenerator<T>. This is useful when creating withXXX methods that can take either a raw value or a ValueGenerator. First create a core method that takes a ValueGenerator<T>. To provide an overloaded method that takes a raw value, add a method whose body is withXXX(wrapValue(T)).
        Parameters:
        value - the raw value to be wrapped
        Returns:
        a new value generator that will return the given value when its create method is called
